abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Avian and Human
            Influenza Control and Preparedness Project for Lao PDR were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was high; Bank performance was satisfactory and
            borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: collaboration among sectors. The lesson is
            that collaboration across sectors is possible, but it
            requires substantial dedicated resources and an impartial
            lead partner. An emergency and interest from senior leaders,
            technical teams, agencies and partner countries help
            facilitate coordination as well. Excessive gaps between
            animal health and human health systems persist. The lesson
            is that the next emergency response to a zoonotic disease
            threat should endeavour to more adequately address a key
            factor giving rise to the emergency-the inability of country
            public health and veterinary systems to protect public
            health and economies from infectious disease outbreaks. A
            formal arrangement and positive incentives for cross-support
            will have facilitated the team's work with Ministry of
            Agriculture (MOA). Partner continuity between the emergency
            and a program for medium long-term systemic improvements
            will likely help the transition succeed. The participatory
            design of indicators and their alignment with the national
            plan's overarching objectives supported coordination.
            The systematic supervision approach encouraged coordination
            and is an example of best practice.
